title: Is this sentence correct: “my uncle is passed way”? - Quora

response.answer_text: There is probably no good use for this sentence. I would start by wondering what you mean by “passed way’. I think you meant to say “passed away.” If that is true, then “my uncle is passed away” is an odd archaic usage and may actually never been correct: I honestly don’t know. It might be genuine or it might be a false archaic form. Can you explain the meaning of what you are trying to convey with your language? In other words, are you trying to say that your uncle has passed away (a report of his death) or that he is simply dead (a current state of affairs, hence, perhaps, “ is passed away”) I think in most cases outside of certain and probably bad poetry, we would want to hear “has passed.” but I don’t know the context.”

No. If it's a death announcement; or if you're referring to a very recent death; My uncle has passed away. (…just now) Present perfect.If you wish to include the time of death; My uncle passed away a couple of hours before / a few hours ago.My uncle passed away yesterday/on Sunday/last week/ on seventh October/ last year/in 2017 etc. Simple past.If you wish to say that the death happened before another action was completed; if it is the ‘earlier’ action between two past actions; My uncle had passed away by the time I reached the hospital. Past perfect.
